content.description:
Fantastic route for the 5.11 climber. Despite the space between the bolts, this route is very safe. Do it!

An area classic on beautiful pockets. Crux is at 2/3rds height on thin but positive edges.

Bold, difficult, technical and involved. This is a stunning route to the top of the breathtaking Discovery Wall. Expect small grips, thrilling run-outs and unique movement. It will leave a lasting impression on you, I promise.

Start the same as Martini, when you reach the chains traverse right and establish on the ledge. Don't clip the anchor of Martini. From here fire into the sustained difficulty to the very top, there's one decent rest but otherwise it's on til the bitter end.
content.protection:
6 additional bolts after Martini. 14 in total.

Much like many routes at the Fins, this is not a clip-up... you will be climbing between bolts, sometimes 15 or more feet. There's an easily accessible anchor directly on top of the cliff above this route if you'd prefer to rap in and hang the draws first....

content.description: Stellar movement on awesome holds. This thing is mega good. Get on it!
content.protection: 4 bolts to a chain anchor with biners
content.location: Starts just to the right of Fallout, also the start of Algorithm 5.14d

content.description: Stellar pockets and crimps, low crux to endurance finish.
content.protection: 8 bolts to quick clips. It's a good idea to stick clip the first. There is some chossy rock at the start.
content.location: This route is directly left of Yellowman.

content.description:
Climb the extension to Yellow Man past the Martini flake and up excellent rock following the distinct brown streak.

I have removed any useful description of the climbing so as not to offend overly sensitive MP users.

Think of this route as an easier, less runout sibling to Make it a Double.

Please post a comment if you know the FA info.
content.protection: 8 more draws past the Yellow Man anchor should do it. Hang your own draw on the Yellow Man anchor for pro. 70m rope suffices to lower
content.location: The extension to Yellow Man going up the brown streak.

content.description: Climbing in a tan streak leads to a horizontal break around bolt 4. A large flake feature is on the second half of the route.

Climb up and end at the flake for which this sector is named.

A beautiful route with fun movement.
content.location: Right of Yellow Man. Left of EBR-1.

content.description: An incredible new route that climbs interesting and diverse features to an anchor at just under 100 feet. Begin as you would for Martini - just before the crux of Martini break off to the right and do several big moves between good holds to reach a rest on the far right side of the Martini finishing flake. From here fire through some near perfect stone and very memorable movement -- big spans through edges and pockets, ending with a cross-over pocket move and an accurate standup to a left hand side pull (crux). Journey through the relatively easy run out to the chains but save some juice for clipping! Low in the grade.
content.protection: Bolts to a fixed anchor. 12 bolts?
content.location: Begin as for 'Martini' but break right after the first 7(?) draws, before reaching the ledge. 'Fallout' is to the right, 'Vesper' is to the left.

content.description: A formidable extension to 'Shaken not Stirred' with exceptional rock and a cool position. A short boulder problem meets you just after the chains of Shaken, and another one - the redpoint crux of the route, guards the anchor. Several options exist for the final boulder. Do not expect a clip up, this thing is a weee bit airy!

First bolt is a little high due to rock quality, but can be stick clipped from the ledge. Climb Yellowman-esque pockets to a ledge at 3/4 height. Continue through a blank section to the (shared) Martini anchor.
content.location: Tucked in between Yellowman and Martini

content.description: A tricky little route with mostly positive holds, a nice addition to the wall. Get on it, quite fun movement.
content.protection: 6-8 bolts to a chain anchor with biners.
content.location: On the Pillar just downhill from Chapstick. Hazmat is the right of the two routes which both share the same anchor.

content.description: This route has two bouldery cruxes, one at the halfway point, and another near the top.
Balancy crux at the start leads to excellent pockets. Pumpy finish.

Start on the far left of the choss band.  Make some hard/bouldery moves on sharp holds off the ledge and past the first 3 bolts.  Continue up on amazing pockets.  This route was originally equipped to go right at the second to last bolt and end on Shaken's anchors.  It now has its own anchor straight up.

content.location: The furthest left route on the Discovery wall. Shares an anchor with Hazmat on the shorter almost discrete wall just before the gully separating the Discovery and Yellowcake walls.

content.description: Begin on a vertical section of pockets and crimps. Jog to the right and pull onto the upper slab enjoying chert holds near the anchors.
content.location: This route is at the base of the Discovery Wall just right of Hazmat and left of Pure Rock Fury. There is a short slabby break in the routes between Chapstick and Hazmat.

content.description: Standard bubble climbing.  A nice addition to the warm-ups.

Tech your way through small holds for a few bolts, then wander through a sea of chalk-less rock above.

This is the way it's spelled in the topo posted by Jonathan.
content.location: Between Pure Rock Fury and Dinner Roll.

content.description:
Idaho's hardest sport route.

From first ascensionist Jonathan Siegrist's description (with permission):

"The climb begins with a pumpy and cool 13a called 'Son of Discovery', before breaking dramatically right as the grips gradually decline to a sequential, powerful and very low percentage mid-height crux. One specific move in this crux thwarted me repeatedly. Pure difficulty was certainly an issue, but mainly it is characterized by an off balance, super accurate and long move. At best I was doing this move 1 of every 3 or 4 times from the hang. Linking it from the ground was going to be a heinous task. A few hard exit moves take you into easier terrain and the main rest. Above the rest, an ultra thin, beautiful headwall, 60 feet or more in length remains. The meat of this section is 2 well spaced bolts long, and requires finger strength, creative thinking and a surprising amount of power. The final bolt is crimpy 12+/13- terrain to the top... pulling up over 40 meters of rope to clip."

Needless to say, I have not climbed this route! (Nor has anyone else . . . yet.)

EDIT: Paige Claassen claims the brilliant second ascent September 2018.
